learning_outcomes.description: Understand the stages of quantitative research
Understand how social theories are related to social scientific concepts
Be able to calculate and interpret basic univariate descriptive statistics
Be able to construct and interpret two and three-way cross-tabulations
Understand the logic of classical statistical inference
Be able to make statistical inferences based on a sample mean/proportion or comparison of means/proportions
Be able to carry out a chi-squared test of statistical independence for tabular data
Be able to construct and interpret a correlation coefficient
Appreciate the logic of bivariate linear regression
Be able to use Jamovi statistical software to access and manipulate survey data in preparation for quantitative analysis
Be able to use Jamovi statistical software to carry out simple descriptive and inferential statistical procedures

assessments.task_description: This is a multi-choice and short response exam that contains 40 questions assessing students' knowledge of statistical concepts learnt in the lectures and tutorials. The questions will assess both knowledge and capacity to interpret statistical information.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
This assessment item consists of a mix of statistics/data analysis problems that must be completed using Jamovi software for analysis. The computer exercises will be posted to UQ Ultra in Week 8.

You must upload your assignment as one file that contains three parts to a Blackboard link. Part A includes a section on hand calculations. Part B includes a section on Jamovi software based exercises. Part C is a statement of transferable skills. 

Part A focuses on manual calculations (3 questions total)

Part B focuses on Jamovi calculations (7 questions total)

Part C focuses on real world applications and definitions (3 questions total)

Marking criteria and/or marking rubrics are available in the ‘Assessment’ folder in Blackboard for this course.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You must submit your assignment electronically by the due time, on the due date.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
Quiz 1 (week 3) 12/08/2025 - 14/08/2025

Quiz 2 (week 6) 2/09/2025 - 4/09/2025

Quiz 3 (week 11) 14/10/2025 - 16/10/2025

Each review quiz will be due 48 hours after it is assigned.

Quiz 1 (week 3) will be open Tuesday 12th August 2pm, due date 14th August 2pm.

Quiz 2 (week 6) will be open Tuesday 2nd September 2pm, due date 4th September August 2pm.

Quiz 3 (week 11) will be open Tuesday 14th October 2pm, due date 16th October 2pm.
assessments.task_description:
In weeks 3, 6 and 11 there will be review tests that are designed to help you a) practice for the mid-semester exam, and b) make progress on your assignments. There are 3 tests to complete over the semester.

The tests can be found on the course site under the Assessment tab. They are to be submitted online within 48 hours from when the date and time the test opens. Tests are set up as online quizzes. Solutions will be made available on the blackboard site after the due date, and no late submissions will be accepted without prior approval from the course coordinator. If you are unable to complete the tests within the given period you will need to apply for a deferred exam no later than 5 calendar days after the due date. 

Tests are not graded by the course coordinator or the tutors - they are graded automatically through blackboard. It is your responsibility to look at the answers provided. Tests are graded out of a total of questions across the semester answered correctly. These must be completed by the due dates. Each week, the number of questions will vary - some weeks might have 10 questions, others might have only 4 questions. This reflects the time needed to complete each set of questions.

Further details about tests will be provided in week 1 of the semester.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

This introduces the course and describes the stages of social research, with an emphasis on quantitative research design.

learning_activities.topic:

This lecture describes how information gathered from a sample can be inferred to the population. Includes the use of confidence intervals.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Inferential Statistics: Confidence Intervals This lecture describes how information gathered from a sample can be inferred to the population. Includes the use of confidence intervals.

Learning outcomes: L10, L11
learning_activities.topic_description: WEEK 8 - Confidence Intervals Calculate and interpret confidence intervals using Jamovi

learning_activities.topic:

This lecture describes how information gathered from a sample can be inferred to the population using hypothesis testing.
